rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 73: Line 73:
===Wittgenstein===
===Wittgenstein===
â
[[Image:Wittgenstein1930.jpg|thumb|right|100px|<small>'''Ludwig Wittgenstein'''</small>]]
  â  
[[Ludwig Wittgenstein]]âs obscurantism is illuminated by the criticism of the limits-of-language proposition presented in the [[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus]] (1921),<ref>see [[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus]]</ref> and in abandoning empirical explanation of linguistic description in later works. [[Friedrich Waismann]] accused Wittgenstein of "complete obscurantism" for betraying empirical inquiry;<ref>Shanker, S., & Shanker, V. A. (1986), ''Ludwig Wittgenstein: critical assessments''. London: Croom Helm,50-51.</ref> this criticism then was developed by [[Ernest Gellner]].<ref>''Words and things: An examination of, and an attack on, linguistic philosophy''. London: Routledge & Kegan Paul, 1979, 1959.</ref> In ''Wittgenstein on Freud and Frazer'' (1988), Frank Cioffi discusses âlimits obscurantismâ, âmethod obscurantismâ, and âsensibility obscurantismâ as the varieties of obscurantism found in the philosophy of Ludwig Wittgenstein.<ref>Cioffi, F. (1998), ''Wittgenstein on Freud and Frazer''. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press, 183ff, chapter 7 on ''Wittgenstein and obscurantism''.</ref>
[[Ludwig Wittgenstein]]âs obscurantism is illuminated by the criticism of the limits-of-language proposition presented in the [[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus]] (1921),<ref>see [[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus]]</ref> and in abandoning empirical explanation of linguistic description in later works. (1998), ''Wittgenstein on Freud and Frazer''. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge University Press, 183ff, chapter 7 on ''Wittgenstein and obscurantism''.</ref>
